(at least they have some sun) for Portland, consider SE area, and there is a KP hospital and medical center in Clackamas. There is good public transit access to downtown. Woodstock area would be handy, and close to Reed College for many concerts and venues. I attend the free rehearsals during Chamber Music NW (July), Chamber Music Northwest and then walk across the street and enjoy the Rhodie garden Portland Parks & Recreation :: Crystal Springs Rhododendron Garden Portland does have a very EZ airport, I often use the SWA $89 fares to seek sun. There are several other nice areas in SE (Sellwood, westmoreland, Johnson Creek) (spectacular ocean views are 1 hr away, Columbia gorge is 30 min) rain / clouds = 200+ days / yr. It doesn't look like Kaiser is available in the dry area of PNW, so Nor CA is the only choice. You might consider getting her closer to family, as that will be important for her transition to single life. 04-15-2009, 03:11 PM 5,138 posts, read 9,323,018 times Reputation: 5262 what about San Diego? 04-24-2009, 03:35 PM 41 posts, read 154,977 times Reputation: 25 No, thank you on San Diego Quote: Originally Posted by loveautumn what about San Diego? Thanks though! 04-28-2009, 01:01 AM Location: Redondo Beach, California 71 posts, read 387,806 times Reputation: 42 Check the premium! All Kaiser premium is not equal. Retired from State of CA I paid no premium out of pocket for Kaiser. If I move to any other state I pay hundreds per month for Kaiser out of state. I had to change to another plan entirely when I moved to Oregon because I could not afford that. If your mother has the medicare option (I'm too young for it) then that may cancel that problem out, I don't know. But check to make sure before making a decision. Kaiser is in very limited geographical areas of each state also so be sure you are within a Kaiser area before making a decision on a state with Kaiser. I really miss Kaiser in So California, they took excellent care of me. This whole PPO thing is a nightmare to me. But the living is better in Oregon for me so that's the trade off. Good luck to your mom. 04-28-2009, 07:59 PM 5,089 posts, read 16,008,949 times Reputation: 7027 If your mother has arthritis which is bothersome, then you should really consider a dry, low humidity area to live. You have ruled out San Diego and you have not mentioned Southern California, so I assume you are not interested in these areas. They would be the best areas to live, on the west coast, for arthritis. You have listed other Kaiser Regions but there is also Colorado. Colorado on the eastern slopes of the Rockies has a mild semi-arid climate with very low humidity. Kaiser is in the Denver Metro area with the traditional HMO. In Colorado Springs it operates under the PPO type plan. However, it has introduced, this year, the expansion of the HMO plan which covers Medicare, to Southern Colorado Cities which includes the cities of Pueblo and Canyon City. These cities are even more dry and are in what is called the "Banana Belt" because of the very mild weather. It attracts many retirees and have good amenities to support a very good lifestyle. I am a covered by Kaiser under their Senior Advantage Plan, the medicare plan, in the the Denver area and I have severe arthritis. This area is good for my condition and I have been using Kaiser for many decades. Kaiser extends very far out of Denver and includes cities like Broomfield, Longmont, Boulder, Louisville and Lafayette. These cities are often listen as some of the best places to live in the US. In addition, a brand new hospital with with a large Kaiser facility attached, has been built in Lafayette. This facility has all the speciality clinics and is a double of the services provided in Denver. You would not have to go to Denver for any care. Though Denver is a great city to live.
